tivity a week. Or we might at least have an Activities-less
Week now and then.
With the student body as small as it is many organizations are cumbersome and useless. We haven't the slightest
doubt that many of them have the highest of ideals—heavens,
no—but certainly it is humanly impossible to realize those
aims under existing conditions. Northwestern decided "respectfully to bury those organizations which have outgrown
their usefulness." How about a little weeding party of our very
own?

WE WERE PARTLY FOOLING!
Some few issues back there appeared in these columns a
plea that the "will to win" be not the only spirit of athletics.
We urged the athletes to regard winning as incidental only.
May we ask that the baseball team will not take us quite so
seriously as it apparently has?

CHICAGO,ILLINOIS

School Founded 825

In 825 A. D. the University was
established by Lotharo, Emperor
of Italy. It was not, however, until 1361 that the school was organized as a university. In 1914
there were 1600 students at Pavia,
the majority being registered in
the School of Law.
"I have not yet formulated any
definite plans as to where I will
go during the summer," said Dr.
Goodnow. He expects to spend
some of the summer in Switzerland, coming back in September.
In Dr. Goodnow's absence Dean
Ames will he acting president.

NEWS LETTER WILL PUBLISH LITERARY
SUPPLEMENT IN JUNE WEEK ISSUE
The News-Letter takes pleasure in announcing the addition of
a literary supplement, to be printed in the form of an extra sheet,
which will be published with an
issue of the paper during June
Week.
This -feattrre-is-under-the-nranagement of Thurston Taylor,'26;

it is sponsored by the Sigma Upsilon Literary Fraternity. Students wishing to contribute short
stories or essays for the supplement may place them in Box 621
or give them to Thurston Taylor
or one of the editors of The News Letter. Copy should be in 1)

tivity a week. Or we might at least have an Activities-less
Week now and then.
With the student body as small as it is many organizations are cumbersome and useless. We haven't the slightest
doubt that many of them have the highest of ideals—heavens,
no—but certainly it is humanly impossible to realize those
aims under existing conditions. Northwestern decided "respectfully to bury those organizations which have outgrown
their usefulness." How about a little weeding party of our very
own?

WE WERE PARTLY FOOLING!
Some few issues back there appeared in these columns a
plea that the "will to win" be not the only spirit of athletics.
We urged the athletes to regard winning as incidental only.
May we ask that the baseball team will not take us quite so
seriously as it apparently has?
